title: 112_hr6014
content: The Act is titled the "Katie Sepich Enhanced DNA Collection Act of 2012" and defines the DNA arrestee collection process for individuals at least 18 years old arrested for or charged with homicide or offenses involving DNA data collection for the National DNA Index System. The Act defines criminal offenses under State law involving sexual acts, kidnaping, abduction, burglary, and aggravated assault punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. The Attorney General will carry out a grant program to assist States in implementing DNA arrestee collection processes. States must demonstrate statutory authorization to be eligible for the grant. The Attorney General will provide grants to States for implementing DNA arrestee collection processes. States must show how the grant will supplement, not replace, existing funds. The grant amount will be based on projected implementation costs. The Attorney General has discretion in determining grant amounts for eligible States. States seeking grants for DNA arrestee collection processes can receive up to 100% of the first year costs. States must have procedures in place for notifying individuals about expungement provisions and eligibility criteria. The expungement process for DNA profiles collected under the Act must be completed within 90 days of request. Any funds needed for the Act will be taken from the DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include a DNA arrestee collection process consistent with the Katie Sepich Enhanced DNA Collection Act of 2012.
